FLATBUSH Yiddish Theater, Klezmer And a Tribute to Israel
Mike Burstyn and Lillian Lux will perform classics from the golden age of Yiddish theater next Sunday to kick off the Jewish Gems Series at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts.

The second event in the series, on March 4, is ''Klez! Klez! Klez!'' This celebration of klezmer music will feature performances by the Yale Klezmer Band, the Hester Street Troupe and the Metropolitan Klezmer.
The final event of the series is ''A Tribute to Israel,'' on April 22. Music and dance from Israel will be celebrated with performances by Ron Eliran and the Parparim Israeli Dance Ensemble.

Jewish Gems Series; next Sunday at 2 p.m.; Walt Whitman Theater on the campus of Brooklyn College, one block southwest of junction of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues; each event $24 or $22, with series tickets discounted; (718) 951-4500.
UPPER EAST SIDE World's Fairs Revisited: Memories of '39 and '64
Many rarely exhibited items are on display in ''Exhibiting the Future: The New York World's Fairs of 1939 and 1964'' at the 92nd Street Y.

The exhibit will be supplemented on Nov. 18 by a multimedia musical ride through a number of world's fairs from 1853 to 1964, titled ''All the World's a Fair.'' The musician Oscar Brand wrote and directed the show and is its host. Mr. Brand worked at the New York fair in Flushing Meadows in 1939, and wrote the music for a film, ''Ballad to the Fair,'' that was shown at the fair in 1964. (Pictured at left are items from the Westinghouse Time Capsule from the 1964 fair.)

''Exhibiting the Future: The New York World's Fairs of 1939 and 1964;'' noon to 4 p.m. most weekdays through Dec. 7; Weill Art Gallery, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street; free; ''All the World's a Fair,'' Nov. 18, 8 p.m., $25; (212) 996-1100.
MUSEUM MILE An Exhibit of Artworks Featuring Social Themes

Fifty-nine artworks from the collection of Ben Goldstein, a native New Yorker who was a labor advocate and garment manufacturer, and his wife, Beatrice, are on view at the Museum of the City of New York in an exhibit titled ''Life of the People: Realist Prints and Drawings from the Ben and Beatrice Goldstein Collection, 1912-1948.'' The works focus on social concerns, and John Sloan and Thomas Hart Benton are among the artists. (Pictured below is ''In the Crowd,'' a 1931 work by Mabel Dwight.)

''Life of the People,'' through Jan. 14, Wednesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesday 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. for registered groups; Sunday noon to 5 p.m.; Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; free, suggested admission contributions: $7 for adults; $4 for students and people over 65; $12 for families; (212) 534-1672.
